Wait, also, Fortran code structure. The original Java has a main method, but in Fortran, the MAIN program is just a program block.

So the Fortran code would be:

program main
    character(len=1000) :: s
    logical :: hasa, hasb
    integer :: i

    read(*, '(A)') s

    hasa = .false.
    hasb = .false.

    do i = 1, len_trim(s)
        if (s(i:i) == 'A') then
            hasa = .true.
        elseif (s(i:i) == 'B') then
            hasb = .true.
        endif
    end do

    if (hasa .and. hasb) then
        write(*, '(A)') 'Yes'
    else
        write(*, '(A)') 'No'
    end if

end program main

Another thing to note: Fortran's .AND. is same as .and., but using .and. in the condition.

Wait in Fortran logical expressions, you can write .AND. (uppercase) but it's also lowercase .and., and case doesn't matter. So "hasa .and. hasb" is correct.

The write statements: Using write(*,*) should work here, as it will just output 'Yes' or 'No' followed by a newline. In Fortran, the * format specifier in the output will format according to the kind of variable, so for a string, it will output the string, and add a newline.

Alternatively, to match exactly the output (possibly without any trailing spaces?), but that's okay. The problem requires just the word Yes or No followed by new line, which this should do.

Also, the program doesn't need to close the output stream since Fortran exits.

Thus, this code should translate the Java code correctly.

Wait but in the original Java code, they create a PrintWriter and then call out.close(). But in Fortran, you don't need to close manually. So no problem.

Another thing: the initial values for hasa and hasb. In the code, I set hasa = .false., hasb = .false. But in the code above, in the variable declaration line, that is:

logical :: hasa = .false., hasb = .false.

Which is okay. Or, alternatively, we can initialize them to false in code.

Alternatively, since they are set to false initially, and then set to true if present, so even initializing to false is okay, but in Fortran variables of type logical if not initialized have undefined values, so initialization is needed.
